title: In praise of slowness - Carl Honore

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of the speaker's talk about slowness?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of speed in modern life

options.label: B
options.text: The benefits of slowing down and living a more intentional life

options.label: C
options.text: The role of technology in shaping our culture

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of social media on our relationships

options.label: A
options.text: He was too busy with work

options.label: B
options.text: He was trying to finish the story quickly

options.label: C
options.text: He was worried about meeting his son's expectations

options.label: D
options.text: He was not interested in reading to his son

options.label: B

options.label: A
options.text: A movement that promotes speed and efficiency

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A movement that focuses on food and cooking

options.label: D
options.text: A movement that only applies to specific industries or professions

options.label: B
options.text: More time for work and less time for leisure

options.label: C
options.text: A greater sense of urgency and importance

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in creativity and innovation

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a cultural taboo

options.label: C
options.text: Because it requires too much effort and discipline

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not possible in today's fast-paced world

options.label: B
options.text: "Bad slow" is being lazy, while "good slow" is being productive

options.label: C
options.text: "Bad slow" is being stuck in a traffic jam, while "good slow" is taking time to appreciate a meal or a conversation

options.label: D
options.text: "Bad slow" is being slow in a meeting, while "good slow" is being quick in a meeting

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's personal experience with slowing down?

options.label: A
options.text: He has always been a slow person

options.label: B
options.text: He used to be a speed addict but has since transformed

options.label: C
options.text: He has never tried slowing down

options.label: D
options.text: He is still struggling to slow down

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to be more productive and efficient

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us to appreciate the moment and connect with others

options.label: C
options.text: It is not important at all

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important for certain professions or industries

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience at the end of his talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That speed is the key to success

options.label: B
options.text: That slowing down is not possible or desirable

options.label: C
options.text: That slowing down is beneficial for individuals and society

options.label: D

title: How to use expertsâ€”and when not to - Noreena Hertz

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's argument?

options.label: A
options.text: Experts are always right and should be followed without question.

options.label: B
options.text: We have become too dependent on experts and need to regain our independence.

options.label: C
options.text: Experts are not necessary in modern society.

options.label: D
options.text: We should only trust experts with advanced degrees.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a study where adults' brains were scanned while listening to experts?

options.label: A
options.text: Their independent decision-making parts were active and engaged.

options.label: C
options.text: They became more skeptical of experts.

options.label: D
options.text: They became more trusting of experts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's suggestion for creating the space for managed dissent?

options.label: A
options.text: Surrounding ourselves with opinions and advice that we already believe or want to be true.

options.label: B
options.text: Bringing in new, diverse, and discordant views into the discussion fearlessly.

options.label: C
options.text: Only allowing experts to express themselves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's idea of democratized expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: Expertise is only for surgeons and CEOs.

options.label: B
options.text: Expertise is not just the preserve of surgeons and CEOs but also shopgirls, best-buy employees, and others within the company.

options.label: C
options.text: Expertise is only for people with advanced degrees.

options.label: D
options.text: Expertise is not necessary in modern society.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about embracing dissent, taking experts on, and democratizing expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: These strategies are not necessary in modern society.

options.label: B
options.text: These strategies are only for experts.

options.label: C
options.text: These strategies are rebellious and will serve us well in dealing with the challenges of the 21st century.

options.label: D
options.text: These strategies are only for certain individuals.

title: Harvard Commencement - J.K. Rowling

multiple-choice.question: What was J.K. Rowling's personal experience of failure, and how did it affect her life?

options.label: A
options.text: She failed to pass her exams, and it led to a downward spiral in her life.

options.label: B
options.text: She had a short-lived marriage, was jobless, and was a lone parent living in poverty.

options.label: C
options.text: She lost her job and had to move back in with her parents.

options.label: D
options.text: She failed to get a scholarship and had to drop out of college.

options.label: A
options.text: She learned about the importance of human rights and the need for social justice.

options.label: B
options.text: She learned about the power of human empathy and the importance of collective action.

options.label: C
options.text: She learned about the value of hard work and determination.

options.label: D
options.text: She learned about the importance of imagination and creativity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the uniquely human capacity that J.K. Rowling believes is essential for social change and collective action?

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to learn and understand without having experienced something.

options.label: C
options.text: The capacity for imagination and creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: The power of human will and determination.

multiple-choice.question: What is the quality of life that J.K. Rowling believes is most important?

options.label: B
options.text: The wealth and material possessions one has.

options.label: C
options.text: The quality of relationships and connections one has.

options.label: D
options.text: The goodness and happiness one experiences.

multiple-choice.question: What did J.K. Rowling wish for the graduates as they began their journey in life?

options.label: A
options.text: She wished them success and wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: She wished them happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: C
options.text: She wished them nothing but the best and reminded them that the quality of life is not measured by its length but by its goodness.

options.label: D
options.text: She wished them good luck and told them to follow their dreams.

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that J.K. Rowling quotes from Seneca, which she believes is a guiding principle for life?

options.label: A
options.text: "The only thing that matters is the length of life."

options.label: B
options.text: "The quality of life is not measured by its length but by its goodness."

options.label: C
options.text: "The power of human will and determination is what matters most."

options.label: D
options.text: "The value of hard work and determination is what leads to success."

multiple-choice.question: What did J.K. Rowling emphasize as the unique status and influence that Harvard graduates possess?

options.label: B
options.text: Their intelligence and capacity for hard work.

options.label: C
options.text: Their nationality and the impact they have on the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to imagine and create.

multiple-choice.question: What did J.K. Rowling hope that the graduates would remember from her commencement address?

options.label: A
options.text: She hoped they would remember her personal story of failure.

options.label: B
options.text: She hoped they would remember the importance of imagination and creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: She hoped they would remember the power of human empathy and collective action.

options.label: D
options.text: She hoped they would remember the quality of life and the importance of living a good life.
